questions.text: The most common mode of inheritance of congenital heart disease is_____.
questions.solution:
The most common mode of inheritance of congenital heart disease is multifactorial.

Multifactorial inheritance refers to traits that are caused by a combination of inherited, environmental, and stochastic factors.

questions.text: As a medical officer working under the RBSK scheme, the commonest congenital heart disease you would encounter is __________.
questions.solution:
Ventricular septal defect(VSD) is the most common congenital heart disease.

The prevalence of congenital heart disease is estimated at 6-8 per 1000 live births.

The relative frequency of major CHD: VSD > ASD = PDA > CoA = ToF

NOTE:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic heart disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

questions.text: As an intern posted in the pediatrics department, you notice a neonate with jaundice and a characteristic blueberry muffin rash. The mother gives an antenatal history of fever with a rash in her first trimester. On examination, he has bilateral cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, and a murmur on auscultation. BERA reveals sensorineural deafness. On cardiac evaluation, which of the following is least likely to be found?
questions.solution:
The classical triad of cataract, sensorineural deafness, and congenital heart disease point towards congenital rubella syndrome. Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not found in congenital rubella infection.

Prenatal exposure to rubella increases the risk of congenital heart defects like:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (Most common)
  • Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Myocarditis

Nonspecific signs of TORCH infections are hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, jaundice, and growth restriction.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A mother reports to you that her baby is irritable and cries all the time. She has also noticed that her infant sweats excessively while feeding. Which of the following findings noted during the examination would you not include under NADA's major criteria?

choices.text: Grade 2 mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area
Grade 3 pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border

questions.solution:
Wide and variable S2 (Abnormal S2) is not included under Nada's major criteria.

Features of congestive cardiac failure, a grade 3 pansystolic murmur with wide and variable S2, and an MDM at the mitral area suggest a diagnosis of large VSD in this baby.

NADA's criteria for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease:

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Pansystolic murmurs are always pathological no matter their intensity.

Short, soft systolic murmurs of intensity <3 are often detected during febrile illnesses, after which they disappear. Such murmurs are called innocent murmurs. Before labeling any murmur as innocent, it should be reassessed after an interval.

questions.text: The most common type of ventricular septal defect is ______.

choices.text: A and B have equal prevalence

questions.solution:
Membranous is the most common type of ventricular septal defect (VSD) to occur.

VSD is the most common congenital cardiac malformation.

Types of VSD include membranous (most common), muscular, inlet/atrioventricular canal defects, and supracristal defects.

Swiss Cheese septum: a special type of muscular VSD with defects in the mid-portion or apical region of the ventricular septum.

Restrictive VSD -A small VSD where the size of the lesion is usually <5 mm. It is associated with normal right ventricular pressure.

Non-restrictive VSD -A large VSD where the size of the lesion is usually >10 mm leading to equalization of pressures in the right and left ventricle.

questions.text: An infant born to a diabetic mother was diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination of the baby, all of the following features can be found except:

choices.text: Ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area
Holosystolic murmur at the left 4th intercostal space
Reverse splitting of second heart sound (S2)
A mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area.

questions.solution:
Wide, variable splitting of S2 is a feature of VSD and not reverse splitting.

The basic defect in VSD is a left-to-right shunt which occurs at the ventricular level. During systole, the left ventricle empties into the aorta and the right ventricle via the VSD, because of which the total amount of blood in the right side of the heart increases, and that on the left decreases. Due to this increase, the right ventricle takes a longer time to empty causing a delayed P2 and on the other hand, the left ventricle empties sooner causing an early A2. This explains the wide S2. Variations due to respiration still happen and hence, the second heart sound is widely and variably split.

Auscultatory findings of VSD include a pansystolic murmur also known as Roger's murmur/shunt murmur can be best heard in the fourth left intercostal space. Flow murmurs that can be heard include, an MDM at the mitral area and an ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area.

A hyperdynamic precordium, a palpable P2, parasternal heave, a laterally displaced apical impulse, and a systolic thrill can be detected on palpation.

questions.text:
A mother is worried about her 4-month-old infant's growth. She says that her infant feeds slowly and often requires periods of rest during feeding. On examination:

Anthropometry: the weight for age is less than the 5th percentile.

Vitals: RR = 62/min, SpO2 -95%,

Palpation: P2 is palpable and the precordium is hyperkinetic.

Auscultation: A grade 3 pansystolic murmur in the left 4th intercostal space and a mid-diastolic murmur in the mitral area.

On a chest x-ray of the baby which of the following is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The above findings are suggestive of a large VSD with congestive cardiac failure. On a chest X-Ray of such a patient pulmonary oligemia is not seen.

“Suck- rest-suck cycle “, failure to thrive, high respiratory rate are features suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. Acyanosis, hyperdynamic precordium, palpable P2,pansystolic murmur, and MDM in the mitral area suggest a large VSD.

In ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is left to right shunting of blood, and this large volume of shunted blood passes through the lungs, which is recognized in the chest X-ray as pulmonary plethora (increased pulmonary vasculature). Other findings seen on a chest X-ray include cardiomegaly with left ventricular apex.

If the defect is large, frank pleural effusion can be seen.

Significant cardiomegaly, prominence of the pulmonary arterial trunk, pulmonary plethora (increased vascular markings seen in the lung fields) can be seen on the X-ray image.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for immunization. She has a loud and harsh holosystolic murmur best heard over the lower left sternal border and is accompanied by a thrill. The chest radiographs and EKG are normal. Echocardiography reveals a small muscular VSD. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch till 5 years and then operate
Restrict physical activity and operate at 2 years

questions.solution:
In patients with small VSDs, parents should be reassured of the relatively benign nature of the lesion, and the child should be encouraged to live a normal life, with no restrictions on physical activity. Surgical repair is not recommended.

Guidelines from the Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young of the American Heart Association (AHA) state that an isolated, small, hemodynamically insignificant VSD is not an indication for surgery. VSDs may get smaller or close completely without treatment, but they won't get any bigger.

Echocardiography is used to estimate pulmonary artery pressure, screen for the development of Left ventricular outflow tract pathology (subaortic membrane or aortic regurgitation), and confirm spontaneous closure.

questions.text:
A good surgeon knows when not to operate. As a pediatric surgeon, on which of the following cases of VSD would you operate?

Case 1- A child with large VSD showing transient improvement in symptoms with better exercise tolerance.

Case 2 - A child with the presence of a mid-diastolic, low-pitched rumble at the apex.

Case 3- A 14-month-old child in whom clinical symptoms and failure to thrive cannot be controlled medically

Case 4- A 6-month-old baby with moderate to large defect associated with pulmonary hypertension, even if the symptoms are controlled by medication

Case 5 - An infant with severe pulmonary vascular disease unresponsive to pulmonary vasodilators
questions.solution:
Severe pulmonary vascular disease unresponsive to pulmonary vasodilators is a contraindication to the closure of a VSD - due to permanent remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature.

Indications for surgical closure of a VSD include:

  1. Patients at any age with large defects in whom clinical symptoms and failure to thrive cannot be controlled medically; 
  2. Infants between 6 and 12 mo of age with moderate to large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension, even if the symptoms are controlled by medication; and patients older than 24 mo with a Qp: Qs ratio greater than 2: 1.
  3. Patients with a supracristal VSD of any size are usually referred for surgery because of their higher risk for developing aortic valve regurgitation

A child with large VSD showing transient improvement in symptoms with better exercise tolerance may be the first sign of developing pulmonary hypertension and indicates an urgent need for evaluation and immediate surgery - the increased pulmonary pressure reduces the amount of blood pushed into the lungs and thereby, congestion transiently.

The presence of a mid-diastolic, low-pitched rumble at the apex is caused by increased blood flow across the mitral valve and usually indicates a Qp: Qs ratio ≥of 2: 1. This murmur is best appreciated with the bell of the stethoscope. 

Surgical risks are somewhat higher for defects in the muscular septum, particularly apical defects and multiple (Swiss cheese–type) VSDs. These patients may require pulmonary arterial banding if symptomatic, with subsequent de-banding and repair of multiple VSDs at an older age.

questions.text: Rahel, a 3-year-old girl who is a known case of congenital heart disease is admitted to your pediatric ward because of low-grade fever with afternoon elevations.  On examination, she is febrile and has painless small erythematous lesions on her palms. Her echocardiography showed oscillating intracardiac vegetation. Which one of the following congenital defects is most likely associated with the above findings?
questions.solution:
The above findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of infective endocarditis according to Modified Duke’s criteria. Patients with high-velocity blood flow lesions such as ventricular septal defect (VSD) and aortic stenosis are at high risk for infective endocarditis.

To make a diagnosis of IE,she has evidence of endocardial involvement (1 major) and fever, predisposing heart condition, Janeway lesions(a painless small erythematous lesion on palms)- 3 minor criteria.

In VSD, a high-pressure gradient across the defect → turbulent blood flow → traumatizes the vascular endothelium → predisposition for infective endocarditis. Important complications of VSD include infective endocarditis and Eisenmengerisation,

High-risk cardiac lesions for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures and invasive procedures like tonsillectomy/adenoidectomy are prosthetic heart valves, prior endocarditis, post-cardiac transplant, congenital heart disease(6 months post repair and unrepaired).

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old child to the OPD. She says that the child has recurrent chest infections, easy fatiguability, and poor growth. You notice a limb abnormality as shown in the image below and find the given X-ray of the child's arm in his medical history. Based on all the findings, you suspect a congenital heart disease. Which of the following conditions are you most likely to find on screening echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of the upper limb shows radial ray defects (absent radius and thumb) and the family history of heart disease suggest a diagnosis of Holt-Oram syndrome (aka hand-heart syndrome). Out of all the syndromes associated with cardiac defects, HOLT- ORAM has the strongest familial tendency - it is inherited in an Autosomal dominant manner.
Holt–Oram syndrome/cardiac limb syndrome is most commonly associated with atrial septal defect (ASD).

Features of Holt-Oram syndrome include:

  • Hypoplastic or absent thumbs, radii
  • Triphalangism
  • Phocomelia
  • 1st-degree heart block
  • ASD

questions.text: A child born to a 35-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, and a protruding tongue. Karyotyping of the child is as shown below. Which of the following is commonly associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings and the karyotyping suggest a diagnosis of Trisomy 21 or Down syndrome. The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

Other congenital defects are seen in some syndromes:

Syndrome Congenital defect
Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) Endocardial cushion defect, VSD, ASD
XO (Turner syndrome) Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of aorta
William's syndrome Supravalvular aortic stenosis, peripheral pulmonic stenosis
Noonan syndrome Pulmonic stenosis, ASD
Holt–Oram syndrome ASD, 1st-degree heart block
Marfan's Syndrome Mitral or Aortic Regurgitation

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum ASD (labelled as 3) is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at the mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

ASD is characterized by an abnormal opening in the atrial septum allowing communication between the right and left atria. There are four types based on their location within the septum:

  • Secundum ASD - most common, usually an isolated abnormality
  • Primum ASD - associated with abnormal mitral valve leaflet (partial AV septal defect)
  • Sinus venous - is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and right atrium. Associated with anomalous right pulmonary venous return to the SVC or RA
  • Coronary sinus type ASD - also called unroofed coronary sinus

Ostium primum ASD: is located at lower atrial septum

Endocardial cushion defect/An AV septal defect/ AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome.

Congenital conditions associated with ASD include:

  • Down's syndrome - usually an ostium primum defect
  • Holt-Oram syndrome - autosomal dominant disorder with upper limb bony defects and cardiac septal defects, commonly secundum ASD
  • Ellis-van Creveld syndrome - chondroectodermal dysplasia associated with postaxial polydactyly and ASD
  • Lutembacher syndrome - combined ASD and mitral stenosis due to rheumatic valvulitis
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.
The soft ejection systolic murmur is a flow murmur heard due to increased blood flow through the normal pulmonary valve. A delayed diastolic murmur can also be heard in the tricuspid area. As the right ventricle now receives more blood, the time required for its emptying is increased resulting in prolonged P2. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2.

Causes of Wide and fixed splitting of S2 include,

  1. Atrial septal defect
  2. RBBB
  3. TAPVC

Other options:

TAPVC -  patients usually present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure around 4-10 weeks of age - this is when the fetal pulmonary vasculature regresses and there is increased pulmonary blood flow which results in early-onset cardiac failure. The physical findings are identical to ASD.

VSD - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include a pansystolic murmur best heard in the left 4th parasternal area and a wide and variable split S2 which is usually masked by the pansystolic murmur.

PS - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second interface and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.

questions.text: A child who used to play for hours together now comes back home and says he gets tired too easily, his concerned mother brings him to you. On auscultation, you find that there is a wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, ECG shows left axis deviation and features of left ventricular hypertrophy. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wide splitting of the 2nd heart sound with left axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) points to the diagnosis of ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD). Wide-fixed splitting of the 2nd heart sound is characteristic of ASD. 

In ostium primum ASD, the basic abnormality is the combination of left-to-right shunt across the atrial defect and mitral insufficiency due to mitral valve clefts. Mitral valvular insufficiency increases the volume load on the left ventricle (seen as LAD & LVH on ECG). When mitral insufficiency is severe enough to cause clinical symptoms like fatigue on exertion, the left atrium enlarges as a result of the regurgitant flow, and the left ventricle becomes hypertrophied and dilated.

questions.text: An ECG finding of right ventricular enlargement in a 2-year-old child is most consistent with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
In atrial septal defect (ASD), there is a left-to-right shunt, resulting in increased blood flow through the right side of the heart, which leads to enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle and dilation of the pulmonary artery, the left atrium may also be enlarged, but the left ventricle and aorta are normal in size.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): There is shunting of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary trunk, which goes into the lungs and then again to the LA and LV. If the ductus is large, left ventricular or biventricular hypertrophy is present.

In ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, but most of the blood is shunted directly to the inflow tract of the pulmonary trunk, so, there is no significant right ventricular hypertrophy. In VSD, the pulmonary artery left atrium, and left ventricle are enlarged.

In Tricuspid atresia, there is right to left shunting of blood through an ASD as the tricuspid valve is dysfunctional due to which the entire systemic venous return enters the left side of the heart using the foramen ovale or through an ASD, and hence, there is left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: During an outreach program, you incidentally discover a child with an asymptomatic ASD. His parents are anxious as they had read on the web about transcatheter device closure and want to know if their child needs one. Your advice is he does not require it, for now, but needs regular follow-up. During the course of follow-up, you would take up the child for transcatheter device closure immediately in all of the following instances except:

choices.text: If the size of the defect is <5mm at 2 years of age.
If the Qp: Qs ratio is > 2:1

questions.solution:
An ASD defect of size <5mm at 2 years of age does not need immediate transcatheter device closure. 
Small ASDs (3 to <6mm in diameter) may grow smaller or close spontaneously. They do not cause symptoms and usually only need observation. 

Transcatheter device or surgical closure is advised for:

  1. All symptomatic patients
  2. Asymptomatic patients with a Qp: Qs ratio of at least 2: 1 
  3. Those with RV enlargement.
  4. ASD size >8mm

Closure (if indicated) is recommended before school entry. Repair is preferred during early childhood because surgical mortality and morbidity are significantly greater in adulthood.

questions.text: As an obstetrician, you discover an atrial septal defect incidentally in a 20-year-old primigravida. You will be watchful about all of the following complications, except:
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis is extremely rare in isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) and antibiotic prophylaxis for isolated ASDs is not recommended. 

ASD is a low-pressure gradient defect whereas a high-pressure gradient across a defect is required to create a turbulent flow, which traumatizes the vascular endothelium, making the patient susceptible to endocarditis.

Patients with a small or moderate ASD are asymptomatic unless a complication occurs. Pulmonary hypertension, atrial dysrhythmias, tricuspid or mitral insufficiency, and heart failure may initially appear during the increased volume load of pregnancy.

questions.text: In a NICU you examine a preterm baby, who has a loud, harsh, continuous, machinery murmur in the Gibson area. All of the following can be found, except:
questions.solution:
A preterm baby with the classical continuous machinery murmur in the Gibson’s area is in favor of patent ductus arteriosus as the diagnosis. Preterm babies with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) have wide pulse pressure, hyperdynamic precordium, and bounding peripheral pulses with a continuous murmur.

If the PDA is large, it can cause overloading of the left ventricle leading to cardiomegaly and congestive heart failure. Retrograde aortic flow, decreased systemic blood flow, and moderate hypotension is common in premature infants with a PDA predisposing them to necrotizing enterocolitis.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in the pediatrics OPD and your professor asks you to examine an interesting case of cyanosis. On examination, you notice the bluish discoloration of the lower limbs but the upper limb and head are pink and on examination of the chest you see a parasternal heave and a thrill is palpable. These findings can occur in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Differential cyanosis can be seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) when there is a reversal of shunt.

Differential cyanosis is manifested as cyanosis of only the lower extremities while upper extremities are unaffected. It is a result of reduced arterial oxygen saturation in the distal aorta compared to that in the aorta proximal to the left subclavian artery.

 It is seen with:

  • right-to-left shunting across a ductus arteriosus in the presence of coarctation or an interrupted aortic arch
  • patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH)

The rest of the options cause cyanosis of all extremities. Among the options, PDA is the only condition that can manifest with differential cyanosis when there is a reversal of shunt.

Image: Right to left shunting of blood flow through a PDA between the aortic arch and pulmonary artery.

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago?
questions.solution:
The right upper limb is the best area to check pre-ductal oxygen saturation in a newborn infant as it receives blood supply primarily from the right brachial artery, which arises from the aorta before the ductus arteriosus.

In routine neonatal screening for critical congenital heart diseases (CCHD), saturation probes are placed on the right upper limb (pre-ductal) and the right lower limb (post-ductal) respectively.

If the difference between pre-ductal and post-ductal saturation is more than five percent, it confirms the presence of hypoxemia. Any reading showing an SpO2 <90% or greater than a three percent difference between the right hand and right foot for three successive readings separated by an hour each would suggest the presence of a congenital cardiac disease.

Screening is done to identify critical conditions before they present symptomatically, and before the neonate leaves the hospital post-delivery. This would allow for early and effective treatment of an underlying disease. 

Critical congenital heart diseases include coarctation of the aorta, double outlet right ventricle, Ebstein anomaly, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, interrupted aortic arch, pulmonary atresia, single ventricle, tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC), d-transposition of the great arteries (TGA), tricuspid atresia, and truncus arteriosus.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a baby delivered via Cesarean section, you hear a continuous murmur. Which of the following would you not include in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Small ventricular septal defect (VSD) characteristically produces a loud, harsh, or blowing holosystolic murmur (not continuous murmur) and is heard best over the lower left sternal border; it is frequently accompanied by a thrill.

Pansystolic or holosystolic murmurs begin almost simultaneously with the 1st heart sound and continue throughout systole (do not spill into diastole like a continuous murmur).

Continuous murmur is a systolic murmur that continues or “spills” into diastole and indicates continuous flow, such as in the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus or other aortopulmonary communication.

Other options:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): The classic continuous murmur is described as being like machinery in quality.

Aortopulmonary window: The findings can mimic those of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) (wide pulse pressure and a continuous murmur).

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformations: Large fistulas are associated with dyspnea, cyanosis, clubbing, a continuous murmur, and polycythemia, commonly associated with Osler Weber Rendu disease.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy starts seizing while playing catch with his father. He is immediately brought to the casualty. On examination, blood pressure in the upper extremity measured as 200/140 mm Hg and femoral pulses were not palpable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here, the diagnosis is coarctation of the aorta because the classic sign of coarctation of the aorta is a disparity in pulsation and blood pressure in the arms and legs (as seen in this patient). The femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak (or absent in up to 40% of patients), in contrast to the bounding pulses of the arms and carotid vessels. Seizure is a complication secondary to systemic hypertension since untreated coarctation can increase the risk for intracranial hemorrhage and hypertensive encephalopathy.

The most common site of coarctation of the aorta is distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery near the insertion of ligamentum arteriosum (juxtaductal coarctation).

DDx: Takayasu arteritis is a chronic vasculitis of unknown etiology, predominantly affecting women with an age of onset that is usually between 10 and 40 years. The disease primarily affects the aorta and its primary branches.

questions.text: A chest X-ray of a patient shows inferior rib notching. Which of the following diseases would you include in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Notching of the inferior border of the ribs (four to eighth ribs) from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is a characteristic finding in the coarctation of the aorta by late childhood.

Causes of rib notching

Superior rib notching Inferior rib notching

Poliomyelitis

Osteogenesis imperfecta

Neurofibromatosis

Marfan's syndrome

Connective tissue diseases

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma
  • Hyperparathyroidism

Coarctation of the aorta

Blalock–Taussig shunt

Superior vena cava obstruction

AV malformation of chest wall

Schwannoma

questions.text: What’s your diagnosis and which is the most common anomaly associated with reference to the X-ray given below?

choices.text: Transposition of great vessels , renal dysplasia
Coactation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
Transposition of great vessels, bicuspid aortic valve

questions.solution:
The given X-ray demonstrates the “3” sign, which is pathognomic of coarctation of aorta. Bicuspid aortic valve is commonly associated with coarctation of the aorta.

3 sign: Indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation, pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinal shadow

Other Chest X-ray features in coarctation of aorta:

  • Dilated left subclavian artery
  • Dilated ascending aorta
  • Notching of 3rd and 9th ribs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels

10% of individuals with CoA have a circle of Willis aneurysm.
